title: Thursday, 11th August, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
PM

Ok!

PM

This is Markets LIve

PM

You don't get an image this morning

11:01 am
PM

You get contrition

PM

Maybe

PM

sit up and pay attention people.

11:01 am
PM

I'm going to invite Bryce to walk back his suggestion that Crispin Wright, director general of the Panel on Takeovers and Merger.

PM

Should be executed in public and generally laughed at

PM

For his complete and utter failure to make ITV do a cough up statement that they were interested in bidding for Entertainment One.

11:02 am
PM

Walk it back Bryce.

PM

The Takeover Panel is perhaps the most august institution in the City, if not the entire world of finance.

PM

And Mr Crispin is, well, what do you say?

11:02 am
PM

Venerable?

PM

Rothschild banker, of course. Doing his Panel service.

PM

Deserves a gong, not brickbats

11:03 am
PM

I've got to say Bryce, that you may have been just slightly wrong to call for his head over this matter.

PM

ITV/Ent 1 does not fall within the panel's jurisdiction.

BE

Go on .......

11:03 am
PM

Canadian company, even if it is listed here.

PM

World and her wife has been on to me about this.

PM

Pointing out that you are taking a literal and isolated view of Rule 2 or whatever.

11:03 am
PM

he Panel's focus is always on the target company.

BE

I see.

PM

The whole idea of the code is to regulate actions and info around a company facing takeover.

11:04 am
PM

So long as that company falls within the Panel's jurisdiction

PM

Which is UK registered or Isle of Man or Channel Islands.

PM

And not Canadian.

11:04 am
BE

Yes, I know all this.

PM

Suggestion is that occasions in the past, when you claim to have seen Panel action focused on a bidder, bidding for a foreign firm,

PM

is where it technically constitutes a reverse takeover.

11:04 am
PM

So you've got to walk it back.

PM

Lift the fatwa on poor Mr Crispin

PM

?

11:05 am
BE

Okay. Perhaps I was being a little harsh.

PM

You sacked the man!

BE

As I say, a little harsh.

11:06 am
BE

But while take on board the invite to walk my criticisms back, I think -- with every respect -- I'll decline.

BE

Let me explain.

PM

omg smile

11:06 am
BE

Here's the code ... Page One.

BE

The Code is designed principally to ensure that shareholders in an offeree company are treated fairly and are not denied an opportunity to decide on the merits of a takeover and that shareholders in the offeree company of the same class are afforded equivalent treatment by an offeror. The Code also provides an orderly framework within which takeovers are conducted. In addition, it is designed to promote, in conjunction with other regulatory regimes, the integrity of the financial markets.

PM

And?

11:06 am
BE

"an orderly framework" ... "designed to promote, in conjunction with other regulatory regimes, the integrity of the financial markets" ....

BE

I concede -- and am fairly sure I said yesterday -- that because of Entertainment One's Canadian domicile it doesn't fall under the statutory basis of the Code, in spite of having a primary listing in the UK.

BE

What I argue is that viewing this through the lens of the Code's statutory basis misses the point of having a regulator in the first place.

11:07 am
BE

Back to the Code again.

BE

[The Code's General Principles and Rules] are expressed in broad general terms and the Code does not define the precise extent of, or the limitations on, their application. They are applied in accordance with their spirit in order to achieve their underlying purpose. In addition to the General Principles, the Code contains a series of rules. Although most of the rules are expressed in less general terms than the General Principles, they are not framed in technical language and, like the General Principles, are to be interpreted to achieve their underlying purpose. Therefore, their spirit must be observed as well as their letter.

BE

So, I question whether ITV was kept to the spirit of the Code's principles as well as their letter.

11:07 am
BE

I was of the understanding that Panel's light-touch, invisible-hand method of regulation was to maintain an honest market.

BE

It was to apply the spirit of the code as well as its letter. A holistic approach, if you want to go into management jargon.

BE

And I suggest that in this case, it failed investors.

11:08 am
PM

! omg smile

BE

Your argument -- "But the Panel Code concentrates on the target and the target company's headquarters are in Toronto," seems to me to just be a long way of saying "more than my job's worth, guv."

BE

My argument remains that ITV should've said something to maintain an honest market.

11:08 am
BE

And the Panel should've used its clout to force that, irrespective of whether it had specific power to do so via some lawyerly interpretation of the specific rules.

BE

That's why I argue, and continue to argue, that the Panel failed.

BE

If we wanted a regulator that applied a rulebook in a ponderous, rigid and lawyerly manner, we could've just left it to the FCA.

11:08 am
PM

You know they're going to call you in Bryce

PM

You'll have to explain this to the director general and three deputy director generals

BE

Yep.

11:08 am
PM

And I'm not bloody well coming with you

PM

Too scary

PM

You have to jump for the Panel

11:09 am
PM

Everyone knows that

BE

I know the Panel's held in high esteem by basically everyone for being an embedded, light-touch regulator. So any kind of criticism of it gets an instant, very prickly response.

BE

But when I see clear and obvious failings in the UK market, I look firstly to the UK regulatory bodies to try to find out why they happened.

11:12 am
BE

In this case, while I understand the TP's reasoning for why the ITV failure happened, I still think it could be seen to undermine the general principles of the body's purpose.

PM

omg smile

BE

So, the criticism stands. It's not walked back. It's just a bit more nuanced, as you'd expect after 24 hours and a lot of passive-aggressive conversations.

11:12 am
PM

Sometimes I feel that I stand between you and The World, Bryce.

BE

Yep.

PM

And on occasions like this Bryce, someone has to have the The World's back.

11:13 am
undefined
PM

Let's try a real life example here

PM

Not Ent 1 or ITV

11:13 am
PM

Shire

PM

Tax-dodger and kid doper.

PM

Headed quartered in Ireland, right?

11:13 am
PM

But Jersey registered.

PM

So, if someone like Abbvie wants to take it over, that's a matter for the Panel.

BE

Yup, for tax efficiencies.

11:14 am
PM

But if, as everyone in London seems to know,

PM

it wants to take over Radius Health

PM

Which is based in New Jersey.

11:14 am
PM

That's not a matter for the Panel.

PM

So there's no forcing Shire into a confirmatory statement.

PM

Even tho everyone knows that it's tabled a bid at close to $80 a share

11:14 am
PM

Valuing Radius at about $3.5bn.

PM

Even tho everyone knows Shire is using Evercore for advice

PM

With financing from RBS and Morgan Stanley

11:15 am
PM

And legal advice from Slaughter & May and Ropes and Gray.

PM

Even tho the Panel could just ring up Francois Maisonrouge and Andrew Sibbald at Evercore or

PM

Or Yannick Perreve at MS, to get confirmation of this.

11:15 am
PM

It's not a Panel matter, cos it concerns a New Jersey-based company

PM

And Shire is the offeror, not the offeree

PM

There are different rules in the States.

11:16 am
PM

And Radius is able to just keep schtum as it tried to play off Shire against ROche Pfizer, Amgen, whoever.

PM

Would you have the Panel intervene here?

BE

Hm.I think it's fair enough to leave this one to the US regulator.

11:17 am
BE

Though using the Prudential-AIA precedent, I'd quite like to see the FCA lean on companies to say something when a rumour is as widespread as the one you've just set out above.

BE

And it certainly is widespread. It's bloody everywhere.

BE

Including in the FT this morning, albeit with rather less detail.

11:17 am
Shire PLC (SHP:LSE): Last: 5,070, down 5 (-0.10%), High: 5,085, Low: 5,040, Volume: 328.20k
BE

I reiterate that Radius has key trial data to be delivered to some conference or other next month.

PM

ah yes

11:18 am
BE

And it came off quite sharply yesterday post a couple of mentions in the UK popular press.

PM

Stale bulls you reckon?

BE

Possibly. Dunno. That'd be my uninformed reading of the price move.

11:20 am
BE

Quick line from Cowen on the pending trial data.

BE

The next anticipated event will be presentation of results from the human replicative
study for the transdermal patch (abaloparatide-TD) – which will be presented at the
upcoming ASBMR meeting during a late-breaking oral presentation on September
19th. Management described plans to host an analyst/investor event centering on
a discussion of this data after it is presented, though we understand this will not
necessarily be on the same day, not at the ASBMR meeting itself. Management
described their intent to advance the TD patch into registrational trials. Though the
actual data has not yet been presented, it would be our sense that the totality of
upcoming plans and commentary (ASBMR, etc.) leads one to reasonably conclude
that the TD patch data seems positive. (We are currently attempting to develop a
better understanding of how to best evaluate the data when presented, based on
references which RDUS management points to of FDA guidance documents on
requirements for demonstrating bioequivalence when using transdermal delivery
platforms.)
For the near-term, thus, we remain confident in our expectation that abaloparatide
subQ is solidly on track to achieve regulatory approvals from the EU and in the US.
In addition, the current version of the TD patch also appears to be positioned to
advance towards a pivotal study. Beyond these milestones, our objectives are to
better understand the dynamics which will influence abaloparatide’s commercial
outlook given evolving market dynamics within the osteoporosis space which are
anticipated to include competitive anabolic agents (Amgen’s romosozumab), and
potential biosimilars to Forteo.

BE

Shares have been as high as $78.60 within the past year so the numbers rumoured re Shire aren't outlandish. But who knows?

t

DFS

11:25 am

BE

I terms of DFS ............

DFS Furniture PLC (DFS:LSE): Last: 256.53, up 32.53 (+14.52%), High: 257.00, Low: 241.10, Volume: 467.22k
11:26 am
PM

Dont know why, but always think of it as a Daily Mail stock

PM

Sofas for white poor angry men, with no taste

BE

They're a big advertiser in the shouty press, certainly.

11:26 am
BE

But yes, guidance upgrade. The demand for really ugly sofas seems to be uncorrelated with a cooling housing market.

BE

FY16 sales slightly stronger than expected and PBT likely to be at the upper end of the consensus range

BE

No Brexit impact.

11:28 am
PM

(Boncoeur - how is it racist!?!!?)

BE

(@fjp73: hadn't heard that. Am not much liking it, as a theory.)

PM

(Dust -- usually knowledgeable sources. We were just taking an innovative approach to RAW)

11:29 am
BE

Here's Jefferies to explain the moving parts.

BE

FY16 sales rise 7%, slightly ahead of consensus. DFS has delivered good FY sales up
7% (JEFe +7%), which we estimate comprises 6% growth in core DFS stores, a c.2% LfL
sales, and a 1% contribution from Sofa Workshop and Dwell stores. In light of these results
DFS expects to deliver FY results inline with our estimates and towards the upper end of
consensus (FY16E PBT range £60.7m to £64.6m), whilst robust free cashflow generation has led to a net debt/EBITDA less than 1.5x for FY16.

BE

trategic initiatives on track. With growth initiatives on track, DFS grew its market share
and now has 11 customer distribution centre's (CDC's) operational. DFS has been trialing
a store-in-store concept with Dwell in converted warehouse space in select DFS stores. This
trial has proven successful, hence DFS has chosen to accelerate the retail space conversion
and CDC programme with a further eight CDC's to be opened in FY17E. As a result, we
adjust our forecasts by bringing forward the associated capex into FY17E and nudge up
FY18E PBT forecasts by 3% as the benefits of the accelerated programme accrue.

11:30 am
BE

Limited Brexit impact, so far. We are encouraged to see that DFS has not seen a
weakening of demand post EU Referendum, which would suggest positive LfL sales. To
caveat this, it only represents six weeks of trading, and trading pre-EU referendum was
already weaker suggesting some pent up demand, and as has already been flagged the
weekly volatility in sofa sales is high. As such, we maintain our -2% LfL sales assumption
for FY17E since we suspect it will take time for Brexit implications to be fully reflected. But
having already downgraded our PBT forecasts by 13% and 23% (FY17E/FY18E) in July there is upside risk should momentum be maintained. Hence with the stock down 24% since Brexit, we remain Buyers.

BE

Fairly sure they're shop.

BE

You'll remember DFS was hammered around the Brexit vote. Went from the 300p flotation price to sub 200p.

11:31 am
BE

So perhaps was due a rally.

BE

Numis too.

BE

DFS has reported a solid trading update, with FY16 sales slightly stronger than
expected and PBT likely to be at the upper end of the consensus range. We are
encouraged that sales have so far seen little impact from the EU referendum,
although we think it would be unrealistic to expect big-ticket demand to remain
unaffected over the coming year. We view this morning's rally in the share price as
justified and see further upside in the valuation.

11:32 am
BE

The shares had fallen by 25% since the referendum up to last night's close, leaving the PE at 8.5x, a 25% discount to the peer group. We believe this justifies the +10% rally seen so far this morning.

BE

Fair enough.

BE

Never wildly keen on companies that rely on selling stuff on credit agreements, even the "zero %" type, but that might be reactive snobbery on my part. And it's certainly more explicable to sell sofas that way than clothes.

11:33 am
undefined
BE

@Helen78 ... on William Hill CVC ......

BE

It's a rumour that pops up about every three months, and has done for about a decade.

11:35 am
BE

The last time we checked, we were led to believe that CVC was perfectly happy building out its bookie portfolio around Sky Bet and Tipco, which it bought in April.

BE

I guess the idea of 888-Rank Frankenconsortium taking William Hill might lead them to reconsider those plans .....

BE

.... but I'd also be surprised if CVC is any more confident about the 888-Rank Frankenconsortium actually pulling this deal together than anyone else.

11:38 am
BE

Davy -- one the best of the sellsides on the turf accountants -- has been through the proposals and concludes this:

BE

Rank and 888 have published more details on their potential
bid for William Hill. The offer is as outlined previously (364p per
William Hill share) – made up of 199p in cash and the remaining
165p in equity. The group would have debt on day 1 of £2.2bn.
The consortium believes that a minimum of £100m in
annualised cost synergies can be achieved (we had previously
worked on the basis of £75m) and that there is a “significant”
opportunity to drive stronger revenue growth as a combined
entity. It is now requesting that the William Hill Board engage
on this proposal, something the latter has once again rejected
to do on the basis that the offer substantially undervalues
William Hill.
Given the confidence that the consortium seems to have in the
potential synergies from such a deal, and the likelihood that
the majority of William Hill shareholders share the Board’s view
in relation to valuation, we suspect a materially higher/more
attractive bid will be required before William Hill will agree to
engage.

BE

.... And the scope for the consortium to pay up from here looks quite limited, given the complexity of engineering required to get to the offer they've made.

11:39 am
PM

Hmm, interesting

BE

Two more observations from Davy, the first being in answer to ....

BE

“Why do we want exposure to Rank via this deal?”

11:40 am
BE

Rank’s inclusion is framed as having two main purposes: to add the necessary scale to
facilitate the transaction (the regulated nature of its earnings stream will facilitate the
debt raise) and, Rank says, it will also help to diversify William Hill’s regulatory risk in
relation to gaming machines in the shops. Rank believes that its own machines business
could potentially benefit from further machine regulation.
Two points here. Firstly, the inclusion of Rank to facilitate the scale to make a deal
plausible should surely be compared with the more straightforward proposal made by
William Hill last year to simply acquire 888. It’s obvious that the majority of the
proposed synergies would still be achievable via an 888/William Hill deal with less
dilution of the overall growth profile and less need to gear up the balance sheet. To us,
the three-way combination still feels like a sub-optimal solution versus this less risky
option.
Secondly, if regulatory risk in relation to the machines is as real as the consortium
suggests that it is (and we suspect it probably is), then what has the consortium
assumed in its base case earnings for the merged entity over the next two to three
years? Does the target leverage of 2.5-3x by 2018 build in an adequate margin of safety
for adverse machine regulation or indeed possible UK recession? As we pointed out
yesterday, leveraging up at the current time feels risky to us.
If the operating environment turns out to be markedly worse than the consortium has
built into its base case (either for regulatory or economic reasons), what recourse can
the debt providers take? At what level of leverage, for example, does a dividend not get
paid and are there gearing ratchet levels above which the cost of debt rises further? In
our view, the consortium will need to provide more detail on the precise debt structure
if William Hill shareholders are to get comfortable with the proposal, not least because
they are being asked to take on so much equity in the new entity.

BE

And on price .....

BE

This final point is pretty straightforward. On the one hand, the proposal from the
consortium is suggesting that overall annualised synergies will be well in excess of
£100m – that is a very material sum in the context of an expected EBITDA base in 2016
of £536m. Does a premium of just 16% (versus the price on the day before the possible
bid was made public) adequately compensate William Hill shareholders, particularly
when only 55% of the fee is in cash? That is for individual shareholders to decide;
however, to us, it does not seem adequate at all.

11:41 am
BE

I like David Jennings at Davy. He's very good.

undefined
PM

Viking1 -- we are late to this

11:42 am
PM

Sorry, nothing immediate

PM

This card Factory thing is down almost 8% now

PM

Soft trading detail here: http://www.investe...1608110700068552G/

11:43 am
BE

Slowing sales.

BE

People are having fewer birthdays, I guess.

PM

In the six months ended 31 July 2016, revenue increased by +4.8% (H1 FY16: +8.0%). As referenced in our 24 May trading statement, first quarter sales growth was softer than levels recently achieved with variability in retail footfall impacting weekly sales patterns. This trend continued in the second quarter, both in the lead up to and following the EU referendum, the wider impact of which remains uncertain.

11:43 am
BE

LFL of just 0.2% for the first half.

PM

8% drop seems a tad harsh tho

BE

Well, if you take the first-quarter update and subtract the numbers from the second, you get an underlying quarterly LFL down around 3%.

11:45 am
BE

Guidance from management is apparently that it's the online business.

BE

Cardfactory.co.uk was relaunched last April so there's an annualisastion effect, apparently.

BE

Morgan Stanley can talk us through the rest.

11:46 am
BE

- Although there was not, we are told, much slowdown in the in-store LfL
quarter on quarter, the in-store LfL for FY H1 of -0.1% is still significantly
weaker than for the same period last year (+2.7%). Average spend showed
"strong growth", so the issue appears to have been one of declining
transaction volumes, with the company citing poor high street footfall. Whilst
this is consistent with statements from other retailers, we think there may be
some concern today that Card Factory has been impacted by these wider
trends as the stability of demand has been an important component of the
company's investment case.

BE

As I say: people having fewer birthdays. Only explanation.

BE

- The statement makes clear, though, that the space rollout story remains on
track. There were 34 new stores opened in FYH1 (we had assumed 35) and the
company remains on track to open 50 stores for the full financial year (it is
usual for the openings to be H1 loaded).

11:46 am
BE

- Cash generation remains strong and the statement makes clear that the
company intends to continue to return excess cash to shareholders, with an
update on quantum and timing at the Interims next month.
- Despite the weak sales trends, management remains confident in delivering a
full year profit outcome in line with the current consensus range (£80.9m to
£86.7m). We suspect, though that the average (which is currently £84m, giving
EPS of 19.5p) may come down towards the lower end of this range.
- Based on last night's closing price and existing consensus forecasts, Card
Factory is currently trading on 15.0x cal 2017 earnings, 11.4x EBITDA with a
3.0% dividend yield compared to the UK General retail sector on 13.7x, 8.0x
and 3.4% respectively.

BE

Am I wrong in thinking that Poundland etc now sell greetings cards?

PM

Dunno

11:47 am
BE

Not 100% sure either. Will check.

BE

(Incidentally, tried to pick up a card at the last minute from WH Smith in Euston a week ago. Flat pricing, all £4.95. WH Smith's need-gouging is extreme and offensive.)

PM

4.95!?!?!!?!

11:49 am
BE

(I know! And it didn't even come with a free copy of the Telegraph.)

PM

Price gouging at train stations is outrageous

PM

How is it allowed?

11:50 am
PM

State-sponsored robbery

PM

Given that we own the real estate

BE

It's ironic, if you want to see it that way, that government policy has tried to create competition where it damages efficiency -- such as actually running trains -- then promotes monopolies where competition is required, such as selling coffee to the passengers of those trains.

11:51 am
BE

Have UBS on Card thing as well.

BE

The high street footfall weakness seen in Q1 has continued into Q2 and revenue growth was below our expectations. H1 LFL for Card Factory stores was 0.2%. Given poor weather patterns around key trading periods, and the effect of the EU referendum, the weaker trend seems to have been more marked than the gradual long term footfall decline we have seen in the past. There is thus scope for some recovery over the remainder of the year, and management are confident of delivering FY PBT in line with the current range of £80.9m to £86.7m (UBSe £80.9m).

BE

The group reported 6.5% revenue growth in Q1 implying a slowdown to c3.5% in Q2. However, after allowing for the fact that new stores opened slightly later in the period than the prior year, and with some calendar effects, LFL may not have been too much different between the quarters. Some of the group revenue slowdown was also a result of slower growth from Getting Personal. After strong growth in recent years, sales declined slightly in Q2, and a range of initiatives, including strengthened management, are under way to drive the next phase of growth.

11:51 am
BE

Our FY17 revenue growth target of 6.3% now looks challenging, but the group has a good record of managing the business and we expect an offset from lower opex (bonuses, store hours and volume-related expenses). Gross margins may remain under pressure, as successful hedging cannot offset the decline in sterling over the last two years. Over the medium term, if tough sales and margin conditions continue, further industry capacity reduction is possible given lower returns generated by competitors. Further cash returns will also be outlined at the interims, with net debt / ebitda towards the low end of the 1-2x target.

undefined
PM

Kadhim reports strong interest in the football leage

11:52 am
PM

Sign up here: http://ftalphavill...y-football-league/

PM

There's other football stuff also

PM

Gary Paulin

11:53 am
PM

Using the new season to discuss Northern Trust's interst in e-gaming etc

PM

With the start of the English Premier League just two days away one of the fiercest rivalries is expected to reignite with Mourinho at Man-U and Guardiola at Manchester City. But it isn't only on the pitch where the battle is heating up. Manchester City struck first with the signing of a “fantastic, young, talent…full of potential” some weeks ago. But it wasn't the traditional signing you might expect. It is an 18-year old gamer Kieren ‘Kez’ Brown. Kez will play for Man City in the biggest football eGaming franchise FIFA 17 (from NTCM Buy rated EA), live stream on Twitch, make videos for the club’s YouTube channel and represent the club in eSports tournaments.

Now Manchester United have struck back with some force and has signed a deal with EA itself. Last night the two companies announced a three year global partnership. EA's FIFA 17 game (released late September) will be promoted across Manchester United social media channels and the narrative mode of the game, staring Alex Hunter, a young apprentice who gets his shot at the big time, will begin his life at Old Trafford. Gaming pods will be set up at Old Trafford and at the training complex. Man United plan online campaigns to enable fans (659 million of them according to MUFC) to get access to exciting content, including interactive experiences and social campaigns.

"This announcement will no doubt excite many of our younger fans, and indeed some of our players, who will have grown up with the franchise and other EA SPORTS phenomena." MUFC MD Richard Arnold.

It isn't only in Manchester that traditional sports is embracing the growing influence of the socially led eGaming and eSports phenomenon. Valencia, West Ham, Sporting Lisborn, Wolfsburg and FC Shalke have all recently become involved. It just remains to be seen what the greatest club of them all, Liverpool (Ed!), will come up with.

PM

Live streaming and fast broadband has seen the number of eSports enthusiasts grow eight-fold in four years, largely in the absence of mainstream media coverage. There is a substantial increase in eSports awareness and the number of consumers worldwide that are aware of eSports will surpass one billion this year (source: Newzoo Global Esports Market Report). The explosive growth of eSports awareness is not coincidental in our view. It is attributed to three things: increased involvement of mainstream media and broadcasters, a huge effort by publishers to build their eSports business and explosive growth in leagues and events organized on global, regional and local scales.

While eSports hasn’t yet gone mainstream with respect to mainstream media coverage, the self-proclaimed leader in sports broadcasting – ESPN – has every intention of covering the same. “We’re seeing the same pictures as everyone else of packed stadiums filled with people going crazy,” said John Lasker, VP of programming and acquisitions for ESPN Digital Media. To capitalize, ESPN is building an infrastructure to so that it can effectively serve as both a broadcaster of top competitions and an editorial resource for those interested in following the latest news, results and trends.

And where the interest in eSports grows, so goes the money. The biggest single eSports event, the Dota 2 championship finals, is this weekend. The prize pool for the final on Saturday now stands at $20,288,019. We think there is every possibility that eGaming is also set for the start of a new phenomenon; the rise of GaaS (Gaming as a Service). One which can lead to substantial opportunities for revenues, higher margins, and a re-rating of the stocks exposed. How to get exposure? Our 13-stock global eGaming basket provides exposure to the gaming publishers, the enablers, monetizers and peripheral beneficiaries.

PM

Our operations are managed on a
regional basis, and are primarily
focused on the airport and
railway station markets. During
2015, 54.0% of our revenues
were generated in the air sector
and 39.5% in the rail sector.

BE
